title: Quiz 3: Surgery FQE (Feb 2023)
description: Surgery Final Qualifying Examination from February 2023. Covers General Surgery, Trauma, Orthopaedics, and Neurosurgery.

questions.question: The most common hernia in females is:
questions.explanation: While inguinal hernias are the most common overall, Femoral hernias have a much higher incidence in females compared to males due to pelvic anatomy.
questions.hint: Think about the wider female pelvis.

questions.question: The pathophysiology of acute appendicitis relates to:
questions.explanation: Obstruction (by fecalith or lymphoid hyperplasia) leads to distension, ischemia, and infection.

questions.question: The most helpful initial diagnostic imaging for intestinal obstruction is:
questions.explanation: Plain films (erect and supine) demonstrate air-fluid levels and dilated loops, which are hallmark signs of obstruction.

questions.question: regarding airway and cervical spine mobilization, choose the FALSE statement:

options.text: Maintain cervical spine immobilization in all unconscious or symptomatic patients with cervical collar.
Inspect the chest movements and any signs of respiratory distress.
Inspect the mouth for any debris and sweep through
Perform chin lift/head tilt to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

questions.explanation: In trauma, the Head Tilt-Chin Lift is contraindicated due to C-spine movement. The Jaw Thrust maneuver is used instead.

questions.question: Which of the following enhances wound healing?
questions.explanation: Adequate blood supply (vascular sufficiency) is critical for delivering oxygen and nutrients to the wound.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding an abscess?

options.text: Pus usually extends below the fascia layer.
High doses of antibiotics will dry up the abscess.
After incision and drainage, stitch the incision wound immediately.

questions.explanation: 'Ubi pus, ibi evacua'. Antibiotics cannot penetrate the abscess cavity effectively. Wounds are left open to drain.
questions.hint: You must let the pus out.

questions.question: The following modalities can be used in the main management of hydrocephalus EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: End-to-end anastomosis is a vascular or bowel technique, not a treatment for CSF drainage.
questions.hint: One of these connects blood vessels or gut, not brain ventricles.

questions.question: The following is a primary brain injury:
questions.explanation: Primary injuries occur at impact (concussion, contusion). Hematomas are often considered secondary sequelae of vascular damage.
questions.hint: Happens at the exact moment of impact to the tissue.

questions.question: Abdominal pain on the right iliac fossa:

options.text: May suggest a urinary tract infection.
An associated mass could originate from the prostate gland.
Is an indication of liver failure

questions.explanation: RIF pain is the classic presentation for acute appendicitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is correctly matched with its cannula gauge?
questions.explanation: Yellow=24G (Paeds), Blue=22G, Pink=20G, Green=18G, Grey=16G, Orange=14G.

questions.question: In management of trauma patients, the 'golden hour' refers to:

options.text: Interventions that prevent secondary injuries and death within the first hour.
The hour before the accident happens.
The time taken to reach the hospital.

questions.explanation: The Golden Hour is the critical time window post-trauma where prompt resuscitation maximizes survival.

questions.question: Thermal burns include:
questions.explanation: Any burn caused by external heat sources (liquid, flame, flammable agent) is a thermal burn.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for 3rd degree burns?
questions.explanation: Full thickness burns are leathery, painless (nerves destroyed), and do not blister.

questions.question: In surgical history taking, which statement is true?

options.text: History of presenting illness is written in patient's exact words.
PMSH includes 'patient is a known diabetic on treatment'.
Specific age need not be indicated.

questions.explanation: Diabetes status belongs in Past Medical/Surgical History (PMSH). Appearance is Examination. HPI is a narrative (Complaint is in own words).

questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).

options.text: Eye opening to pain is graded as 3
Uttering inappropriate words is graded as 4.

questions.explanation: GCS ranges from 3 to 15. Eye opening to pain is 2.
questions.hint: You get 3 points just for being there.

questions.question: In fractures, Varus deformity means:

options.text: Distal segment is angled towards the midline of the body.

questions.explanation: Varus = Distal part towards midline (Bow-legged). Valgus = Distal part away from midline.

questions.question: Which nerve injury is associated with fracture mid-shaft humerus?
questions.explanation: Radial nerve runs in the spiral groove of the humerus.

questions.question: Which of the following is a complication of fractures?

options.text: Cerebral vascular accident from fat embolism

questions.explanation: Myositis ossificans is calcification in muscle following trauma. AVN affects femoral neck, not condyles. D describes Non-union.

questions.question: A flail chest is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Paradoxical movement (in on inspiration, out on expiration) is the hallmark.
questions.hint: The chest moves the wrong way.

questions.question: Closed fracture reduction:

options.text: May fail if soft tissues are interposed.
Is not applicable in intra-articular fractures.
Is not necessary in un-displaced fractures.

questions.explanation: Soft tissue (muscle/periosteum) getting stuck between bone fragments prevents closed reduction, necessitating open reduction.

questions.question: Internal fixation may be achieved with all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Traction is a method of external splintage/reduction, not internal fixation.
questions.hint: One of these is outside the body.

questions.question: In management of an open fracture, which statement is true regarding debridement?

options.text: External fixator pins go through the fracture.
Small bony fragments with no attachment should be removed.

questions.explanation: Devitalized bone acts as a foreign body and infection risk.

questions.question: Cardiac tamponade is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Pulsus Paradoxus (drop in SBP on inspiration) is a classic sign. Neck veins are distended.

questions.question: A Surgical airway involves:
questions.explanation: Tracheostomy (and Cricothyroidotomy) are surgical airway procedures.

questions.question: Biliary stones form primarily as a result of:
questions.explanation: Lithogenic bile (supersaturated with cholesterol) leads to precipitation and stone formation.
questions.hint: Too much solute, not enough solvent.

questions.question: Acute cholecystitis is associated with which sign?
questions.explanation: Murphy's sign (inspiratory arrest on RUQ palpation) is specific for cholecystitis.

questions.question: Dinnerfork deformity is a feature of:
questions.explanation: Distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement.

questions.question: In acute urinary retention:

options.text: Is less painful than chronic retention.
A suprapubic cystotomy is useful in emergency relief.

questions.explanation: If urethral catheterization fails, SPC is the emergency procedure. Acute retention is painful (unlike chronic) and usually <1L.
questions.hint: When you can't go through the urethra, go above the pubis.

questions.question: Brown-sequard syndrome presents with:

options.text: Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and motor function.
Complete loss of vibration sense only.

questions.explanation: Hemisection of the cord: Same side motor/proprioception loss, opposite side pain/temp loss.

questions.question: How should bleeding from the scalp be controlled initially?

options.text: Apply constant pressure to the bleeding area.

questions.explanation: Direct pressure is the first aid for scalp bleeding.

questions.question: Which feature is NOT associated with hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: Palpitations are a sign of Hyperthyroidism (Tachycardia).

questions.question: Benign Prostrate Hypertrophy is best assessed on:
questions.explanation: TRUS allows accurate volume measurement.

questions.question: Septic arthritis:
questions.explanation: Can be caused by joint injections or surgery (iatrogenic).

questions.question: Avascular necrosis is a common complication of:
questions.explanation: Disrupts blood supply to the femoral head.

questions.question: Which statement is true about haemorrhoids?

options.text: Internal haemorrhoids originate above the dentate line.

questions.explanation: Internal are above the dentate line and usually painless.

questions.question: Which is NOT a treatment for chronic osteomyelitis?
questions.explanation: Steroids suppress immunity and worsen infection.

questions.question: A key differential diagnosis of haematuria is:
questions.explanation: Malignancy must always be ruled out in haematuria.

questions.question: Regarding undescended testes:

options.text: Trans-inguinal migration occurs between 28-40 weeks gestation.

questions.explanation: Descent happens late in pregnancy. Surgery is done much earlier than 15 years (6-12 months).

questions.question: Which is NOT an indication for operative treatment of fractures?
questions.explanation: Closed stable fractures are treated conservatively (cast).
questions.hint: If it's stable and closed, why operate?

questions.question: Compartment syndrome is treated by:
questions.explanation: Surgical release of pressure is mandatory.

questions.question: Match the surgical term to its definition.

pairs.right: Abnormal connection between two epithelial surfaces
Grating sound/sensation from bone friction or gas

questions.explanation: Definitions of common surgical terms.
questions.hint: Match the procedure to the description.

questions.question: When palpating a mass, which characteristics should be assessed? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The 'Student's Guide' to a lump includes 3S, 3T, 3C, F, M etc.

questions.question: Select the components of Conservative Management for Intestinal Obstruction ('Drip and Suck').
questions.explanation: Conservative management involves resting the bowel (NPO), decompressing (NGT), and rehydrating (IVF).

questions.question: Match the Gustilo-Anderson Classification of Open Fractures.

pairs.right: Extensive damage but adequate soft tissue coverage
Extensive loss, periosteal stripping, needs flap

questions.explanation: Classification based on wound size, soft tissue damage, and vascular injury.
questions.hint: I is small, III is severe.
